title_sort: john m. rogers to walt whitman, 24 july 1875
title: John M. Rogers to Walt Whitman, 24 July 1875
text: New BritainJuly 24th 1875.Dear Friend and FatherI received your letter last EveEvening and was glad to hear from you but I am sory[sorry] to hear that you have sick so long I have been sick with the Chills & Fever I have had wine to day my wife and Child have gone home on a visit to her house at Norwalk ConnConnecticut have been gone cinse[since] the 20th of June so I am alone I am at the same employment yet I have plenty of work but the pay is small My boy was not very well before he went away he has been better cine[since] they have been there they are near the Salt water my wife is well the young Lady you met with me at the CorCorner of Fulton and Cart StsStreets that is my wife. Last wensday[Wednesday] I went to Hartford to the reunion of the ConnConnecticut Vetrans[Veterans] and spent two days I met a good many of my old camrads[comrades] we had a good time there wa[was] asembled[assembled] about Four thousand at charter Oak Park near Hartford. I have grown thin cince[since] you last saw me I do not weigh so much in 125 lbspounds I have worked very hard this sumer[summer] and I do not think it agrees so well with me hered[here] as it does near the salt water and I shall not stay here any longer than I can help so good by[bye] for this timeI remain yours &cJohn M. Rogers John M. Rogers to Walt Whitman, 24 July 1875
